questions.question: ……………………….. people agree with me.
questions.description: Most and many are possible here with slightly different meanings.

questions.question: We meet ……………………….. few days.
questions.description: In a few expressions that refer to time intervals we can use every before a plural noun.

questions.question: …………………………….. these keys opens the door.
questions.description: Before a noun with a determiner (my, this, any etc.) we use neither of.

questions.question: ………………………………. people invited to the party didn’t turn up.
questions.description: We use some, not some of, before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: ………………………….. the shops remain closed on Sundays.
questions.description: We use most of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: ………………………….. philosophy is concerned with life after death.
questions.description: Much of is used before uncountable nouns that refer to a subject of study.

questions.question: ……………………………. his ideas are impractical.
questions.description: Of can be left out after all, both and half when they are followed by nouns.

questions.question: ……………………………. my children love pets.
questions.description: Of can be left out after all, both and half when they are followed by nouns.

questions.question: He spends ……………………………. his income on video games.
questions.description: Of can be left out after all, both and half when they are followed by nouns.

questions.question: ………………………………. us love music.
questions.description: We cannot leave out of after all when it is followed by a pronoun.

questions.question: ………………………….. them was there.
questions.description: We use neither of before a pronoun.

questions.question: ……………………………… these blouses is loose for me.
questions.description: We use every one of before a noun with a determiner.
